user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemGetInfo(osal_id_t sem_id, OS_bin_sem_prop_t *bin_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(bin_prop);

    memset(bin_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_bin_sem_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_bin_sem_table, token);

        strncpy(bin_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(bin_prop->name) - 1);
        bin_prop->creator = record->creator;
        return_code       = OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl(&token, bin_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_bin_sem_table
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    int32     value;
} OS_bin_sem_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_bin_sem_prop_t *sem_prop)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    /* put the info into the structure */
    sem_prop->value = sem->current_value;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code in the provided fragments appears to modify a function parameter itself (i.e., reassign a parameter variable or change a pointer parameter value). Specific notes:

- OS_BinSemGetInfo: The parameters are sem_id and bin_prop. There are no assignments to sem_id or to the bin_prop pointer variable. memset(bin_prop, ...) and strncpy(..., bin_prop->name, ...) modify the object pointed to by bin_prop, which is permitted by the rule.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: The token parameter is a pointer; the function writes fields into *token (token->obj_idx, token->obj_id), which modifies the object referred to by the pointer (allowed). The pointer parameter token itself is not reassigned.

- OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl: Declared with const OS_object_token_t *token; it neither reassigns token nor modifies the pointer; it uses *token to index tables and writes into sem_prop (allowed).

- OS_ObjectIdRelease and other helper calls: They are called with &token (address of a local variable). The callee functions operate on the object pointed to; there is no evidence they reassign the pointer parameter itself.

- Macros (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) and BUGCHECK: Based on their usage here, they evaluate or take addresses but do not reassign function parameters.

Therefore, no fragments meet Rule 17.8’s prohibition (modifying the parameter variable/pointer itself). If there are other unseen implementations (e.g., definitions of BUGCHECK, OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish) that reassign their pointer parameters, those would need review, but they were not provided.
